div1.head: List of microfilm data on Columbia Barracks Post Hospital in the National Archives, by Philip Showalter Hench, July 1941
div1.p:
MICROFILM OF DATA IN NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Selected by P. S. Hench May, 1941, received July, 1941

list.head: MEDICAL HISTORY OF COLUMBIA BARRACKS POST HOSPITAL
list.item:
1. Entry (printed form) - Monthly Sanitary Report for March 31, 1899.
"Bldgs. completed 15; i.e. 1 surgical bldg., 1 commissary bldg., 1 diet
kitchen, 4 bldgs. used for wards, 4 bldgs. in yellow fever district, 4
bldgs. in small pox district; under construction: 1 mess house for
Hosp. Corps. and one stone (stove?) house. (All this refers to Camp
Columbia, 2nd Division Hosp. 7 A C.) Signed M. C. Brown, Maj.
2. Gen. order 4#20.00 re care of sinks. May 23, 1899.

3. Sanitary report for week ending May 27, 1899 re sinks and sewers which were
inadequate and unsatisfactory.

4. Report re sanitary conditions (incomplete) by Maj. Brown, May 13, 1899, with
various endorsements noting that soldiers are still in tents; barracks
incomplete.

5. Sanitary report. June 3, 1899. Maj. Brown. Much on typhoid fever and no
sewers. Barracks incomplete.

6. Maj. Brown suggests inspection of soft drink and food stands in Quemados.
June 10, 1899.
7. Item re typhoid, June 7, 1899.
8. Special sanitary report, June 16, 1899, re outhouses.

9. Sanitary Report, June 24, 1899. Troops to move into Barracks about July 1
but sewage system still inadequate.

10. Inspection of Tropical Brewing Co. June 23, 1899. Major Ira C. Brown, Post
Surgeon. Endorsed by Maj. Kean and others.
11. Sanitary report for Aug. 8, 1899 - Maj. Kramer.

12. Sanitary report for Aug. -31, 1899 - “Bldgs. completed except Post Hosp.”
Col. Randall.

13. Sanitary report Sept. 30, 1899. Post Hospital completed except diet kitchen.
Capt. Stark. Sewage still inadequate.

14. Inspection of Post Hosp. Columbia Barracks, Oct. 14, 1899. Surgeon in charge,
A.N. Stark. List includes Capt. Stark, Lt. Truby and Contract Surgeons
Gilbert, Pinto, De Porter, Repetti, Soleeby, Wertenbaker. Lists 7 non-
Microfilm of data in National Archives
2.
commissioned officers, 39 privates, 1 contract male nurse and 4 contract
female nurses. Lists 75 patients in hospital (no yellow fever). Total
strength of command served by hospital on day of inspection 35 officers
and 1774 enlisted men.
15. Sanitary report for October 31, 1899. Capt. Stark.
16. Sanitary report for November 30, 1899. Lt. Truby.
17. Sanitary report for December 31, 1899. Capt. Stark.
18. Sanitary report for January 31, 1900. Unsigned.
19. Sanitary report for February 28, 1900. Unsigned.
20. Sanitary report for March 31, 1900. Stark.
21. Sanitary report for April 30, 1900. Stark.
22. Sanitary report for May 31, 1900. Stark.
23. Sanitary report for June 30, 1900. Stark.
24. Sanitary report for July 31, 1900. Unsigned.
25. Sanitary report for August 31, 1900. Stark.

26. Postmortem on Private Traeger; report by Lt. Truby. September 23, 1900.
Acute septicemia.
27. Sanitary report of September 30, 1900. Unsigned.
28. Sanitary report of October 31, 1900. Stark.
29. Sanitary report of November 30, 1900. Stark.
30. Sanitary report of December 31, 1900. Stark.
31. Sanitary report of January 31, 1901. Stark.
32. Sanitary report of February 28, 1901. Stark.

33. Sanitary report of March 31, 1901 written in long hand by Major Kean;
includes “remarks on mosquitoes required by letter from C.S.O. dated
March 27, 1901”. Mosquitoes present at post; source undiscovered.
Observations in Marianao being made. Petroleum being used and buildings
for garrison to be screened."

34. Kean's note: “Two pools affording breeding places for mosquitoes found at culvert
under road to La Playa just west of the hospital.” April 15, 1901.
Microfilm of data in National Archives

35. Note from Maj. V. Havard, Mar. 27, 1901 requesting monthly data re presence
of mosquitoes.

36. April 17, 1901. Letter from H. L. Scott, Adjutant General, directing the
Post Surgeon to inspect Quemados de Marianao, to investigate the prevalence
of mosquitoes and methods of elimination, to inspect all hospitals in
which fever cases are admitted to see whether the provisions of circular
letter of March 15, issued by the Supt. of Charities, by order of the
military governor, are being complied with; etc.

37. Sanitary report for April 30, 1901. Mosquitoes diminishing, screens being
installed at the Post but not yet at the hospital. Recommendation that
ward buildings A, B and C and the yellow fever wards be screened and
cages be constructed in receiving ward. Signed by Major Kean.

38. (page 34) Note by Major Kean resuperiority of copper wire over galvanized
wire. May 6, 1901.

39. May 9, 1901. Report by Maj. Kean (his own handwriting) reinspection of
Quemados and Marianao. Mosquitoes breeding by thousands in nearly
every patio. Of 26 houses inspected by him and Amador 25 had larvae
in water barrels. Culex pungens and stegomyia (fasciatus).

40. (page 35) Report of Maj. Kean May 9, 1901 to Chief Surgeon, Dept. of Cuba
re conditions in Quemados and Marianao. Mentions contract surgeon
Rafael T. Echeverria as sanitary officer under Lt. Harry T. Jackson
of the artillery corps who was in charge of sanitary matters in
Quemados (i.e. Jackson). Mentions inspection of prostitutes by Dr.
Edouard Angles, the municipal physician.

item.p:
41. (p. 36). Sanitary report for May 31, 1901 by Capt. Edward F. Horr(?). Horr
Recommends that hospital buildings be screened and cages built (appar-
ently not done yet).

list.item:
42. (p. 37). Report of Capt. Horr, June 10, 1901 to the chief surgeon re
Quemados and Marianao. Still many mosquitoes breeding.

43. (p. 38) Sanitary report of June 30, 1901 by Capt. Horr. Mosquitoes less
abundant. Screening of hospitals and buildings commenced.

44. (p. 39) Report to the Chief Surgeon by Capt. Horr July 3, 1901. Mosquitoes
still breeding ( Cuban citizens dump water when they see inspectors
coming).
45. (p. 41) Sanitary report, Aug. 1, 1901. Capt. Horr.

46. (p. 41) Report to Chief Surgeon. Two cases of yellow fever in Quemados
(one fatal).
47. (p. 43) Monthly Sanitary report, Aug. 31, 1901. Horr.
48. (p. 44) Report to Chief Surgeon. Sept. 7, 1901. Mosquitoes not abundant. Horr.

Horr
JRK
Microfilm of data in National Archives

49. (p. 45) Sanitary report of Columbia Barracks, Sept. 30, 1901 - Horr. Capt Edward F
Horr. M C
50. (p. 46) Sanitary report re Quemados to chief surgeon - Oct. 9 - Horr.
51. (p. 47) Sanitary report of Post - Oct. 31, 1901 - Capt. Howard.
52. (p. 48) Sanitary report re Quemados and Marianao. More mosquitoes. Nov 9, 1901 Capt. Howard.
53. (p. 49) Report re Post - no mosquitoes. Nov. 30, 1901. Howard.
54. (p. 50) Report re town - Amadosr. (JRK)

55. (p. 52) Report re town - Dec. 11, 1901. Mentions Echeverria, the sanitary
inspector. Howard.

56. (p. 53) Mosquitoes found near Paint Shop of Post; Amador, Dec. 12. Then
follows many similar reports re inspection of post and town for mosquitoes
signed by Howard, Lt. Col. Havard, etc. By Jan. 31, 1902 practically
no mosquitoes at Post and fewer in town. The History of the Post stops
on page 01; date of May 7, 1902. Page 82 - 300 are blank. On page 301
is a note re the marriage of Private Wm. Douglas. That concludes the
Medical History of the Post.

list.head: Walter Reed's letters to the Adj. Gen. reporting his whereabouts:
list.item:
Left Havana, Feb. 9, 1901, arrived Washington, Feb. 12 and resumed
duties as Curator of the Army Med. Museum.

During month November, 1900 was at Columbia Barracks, Cuba as
“president of a board of medical officers investigating infectious
diseases prevalent on the Island of Cuba.”
From Sept. 1 - Sept. 25, 1900 - Curator Army Med. Museum, Washington.
From Sept. 26 - Sept. 30 enroute from Washington to Havana.
Microfilm data from National Archives
(Oct. 1-13, 1900. At Camp Columbia.
(Oct. 14-20, enroute to U. S.
(Oct. 21-27, delegate to American Public Health Assoc. at Indianapolis.
(Oct. 28-31, awaiting departure of steamer for Cuba.

During July, 1900 at Columbia Barracks as “President, etc.” also
investigated yellow fever at Pinar del Rio Barracks, per par. 4 S. O.
65 Hdqrs. Dept. of Havana and Pinar del Rio July 21, 1900.
(June 1-18, 1900, Curator Army Med. Museum.
(June 19-25, enroute to Havana

Order from Sec. of War to Reed to return to Washington instead of
Cuba Oct. 20, 1900.

Special order 246, directing Reed (in Washington) to go to Indianapolis,
Oct.22-26, 1900.
__________________________________________________

Letter (Oct. 19, 1900) of Sternberg to the Adj. Gen. recommending Reed
as delegate to Indianapolis Oct. 22-26, 1900 to make an “important
communication” re Y.F.
__________________________________________________

Special order #15 Adj. Gen. office, Jan. 18, 1901 ordering Reed to
return to Washington from Havana after the Pan Amer. Med. Congress
(Havana) to continue his investigation at the Army Med. Museum (Wash.)
with reference to the cause and prevention of Y.F.

Also Sternberg's letter (Jan. 17, 1901) recommending this order.
__________________________________________________

List of Disinterment at Post Cemetery, Columbia Barracks, Cuba during
the month of Jan. 1901 (disinterred Jan. 31, 1901. List of 58 names
includes Sergt. Sherwood, Maj. Edmunds, Dr. Lazear, Maj. and Mrs.
Peterson, Capt. Page, Maj. Cartwright. Lazear interred Sept. 26, 1900
(disinterred Jan. 31, 1901). Bodies shipped to U.S.
__________________________________________________

List of parcels of land comprising Columbia Barracks - letter dated
Jan. 17, 1901 to Maj. Baker from Lt. Jackson.
__________________________________________________

Letter from Cortelyon, Sec. to the President, to Root, Sec. of War,
enclosing endorsement of President Eliot and the members of the Faculty
of Medicine of Harvard recommending Reed to succeed Sternberg as Surg.-
Gen. (May 26, 1902. “The President wishes to say that he also hears
well of Col. Robt. M. O'Reilly.”
Letter (May 31, 1902) from Root to Eliot.
Letter (May 30, 1902) from Root to Osler.
Letter (May 31, 1902) from Root to Dr. Martin, Lynchburg, Va.

Letter (Feb. 4, 1901) from Quartermaster's agent acknowledging
